column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My vitamin D level was a 21 so I was put on 50000 IU's per week for 8 week. After the third week I had diarreha, chills, body aches and then red rash (similiar to a sunburn) on my arms, chest,stomach and legs.

column2: Deceived, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: The doctor assured me that Drisdol Maximum D3 is vitamin D3, or cholecalciferol. IT IS NOT!!!IT IS VITAMIN D2, OR ERGOCALCIFEROL!!! It is made by irradiating mushrooms. Dr. R Vieth, a prominent researcher, has concluded that vitamin D2 should not be regarded as a nutrient suitable for supplementation! I discovered it was D2 when my blood test showed both vitamin D2 and D3. The first person I talked to at the pharmacy where I got the drug told me it was vitamin D3, but I later talked to a pharmacist who agreed it is D2. She said my doctor had prescribed D3 but in doses that was only available as D2, so they called my doctor who said to give me the D2. The pharmacist said it happens frequently that doctors prescribe vitamin D3 in doses only available as D2, and no wonder since the drug company has deceptively named their vitamin D2 "Maximum D3"!!  My side effects included abdominal pain and bad anxiety.I am surprised that the FDA would allow such deceptive practice!!

column2: newperson, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I had 1/4 of the vitamin D that I should have.  Had all sorts of symptoms associated with low vitamin D levels.  It took doctors 5 years to discover it.  I am now a new person.  Lots of energy.  Pain level drastically lowered. Vitamin D now in normal range. Take it every other week, along with 2000 units daily.  I'm a new person.

column2: Jim, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: 50000 IU capsules on a weekly basis seems to be nothing but a ploy to charge heavy for the prescription drug.  The oral drops of Calcidol and Dridol are 8000 iu/ml.  If one takes 1 ml per day for 7 days, it will be ~56000 iu(8000x7).  In my opinion, the use of Vitamin D on a daily basis is more effective than weekly tablet which just offers only convinience.  In addition drops are more conviniet (mix with food or liquid) than taking a capsule.  I continue to take 2000 iu of Calcidol drops on a regular basis and have well maintained my levels.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been on a 3-month therapy treatment for Vitamin D deficiency (level of 11). Following treatment my level has only increased by approximately 3 points to a level of 14; this is with taking 50000 I.U. per week.
